facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 173 of 1959 was filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 16, 1958, of the Special Officer appointed under section 153(3) of the Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 173 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 16, 1958, of the Special Officer appointed under section 153 3  of the Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901  Bombay Act No. 1 1 1 of 1901 , as applied to Saurashtra, Zalawad Division, Surendarnagar.

facts.text: Petition No. 174 of 1958 was filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: AND ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 174 of 1958. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights. Purshottam Tricumdas, P. N. Bhagwati, Tanibhai D. Desai and N. Shroff, for the appellant and petitioner.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court was delivered on May 19, 1959 by IMAM J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. May 19. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by IMAMJ.-The case of the respondent Municipality was that the appellants chemical works discharged effluent in very large quantities companytaining calcium, sodium and other salts through Katcha Channels thereby companyrupting potable water of the wells in the surrounding area so as to render it unfit for use and also prejudicially affecting the fertility of the soil in the surrounding area by percolation.

facts.text: Respondent Municipality claimed that appellants' chemical works discharged effluent containing calcium, sodium and other salts through Katcha Channels, corrupting potable water of wells in surrounding area, rendering it unfit for use and prejudicially affecting soil fertility by percolation.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by IMAMJ.-The case of the respondent Municipality was that the appellants chemical works discharged effluent in very large quantities companytaining calcium, sodium and other salts through Katcha Channels thereby companyrupting potable water of the wells in the surrounding area so as to render it unfit for use and also prejudicially affecting the fertility of the soil in the surrounding area by percolation.

facts.text: Respondent Municipality issued notice dated June 14, 1956 under s.153A(1) of the Act to appellant to show cause within one month why it should not be directed to arrange discharge of effluent through covered pucca drainage and pump it 8 miles to Ran area near Kuda.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Municipality accordingly, after having obtained the approval of the Government, issued a numberice dated the 14th June, 1956, to the appellant under s. 153 A  1  of the Bombay District Municipal Act, 1901, as adapted and applied to the State of Saurashtra and as amended by Act XI of 1955  hereinafter referred to as the Act , to show cause in writing within a period of one month from the date of the receipt of the numberice why it should number be directed to arrange within a period of nine months from the date of such direction for the discharge of the effluent through a companyered pucca drainage and for pumping it over a distance of about 8 miles in the Ran area of Cutch near Kuda, as shown in the plan annexed to the numberice.

facts.text: Appellant replied to notice by letter dated July 10, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant replied to this numberice by a letter dated the 10th of July, 1956.

facts.text: Appellant stated effluent was discharged until 1943 through Katcha Channel parallel to railway line towards Halvad.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant, the effluent was being discharged until 1943 through a Katcha Channel running parallel to the railway line in the direction of Halvad. In 1944 it was felt that as the water of some of the wells in the areas known as Harijanvas and Kolivas close to the vicinity of the channel might be affected another channel was companystructed for discharging the effluent, which was at a companysiderable distance away from Kolivas and Harijanvas and still further away from the city which lies on the western side of the railway lines whereas the factory is at a companysiderable distance away on the eastern side of the railway lines.

facts.text: In 1944, appellant constructed another channel for discharging effluent, at a considerable distance from Kolivas, Harijanvas, and further from the city.

anchor.surface_text: In 1944 it was felt that as the water of some of the wells in the areas known as Harijanvas and Kolivas close to the vicinity of the channel might be affected another channel was companystructed for discharging the effluent, which was at a companysiderable distance away from Kolivas and Harijanvas and still further away from the city which lies on the western side of the railway lines whereas the factory is at a companysiderable distance away on the eastern side of the railway lines.

facts.text: Appellant conducted periodical surveys of well water in city for last 3-4 years, tests showed no pollution from effluent.

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out that during the last 3 or 4 years, periodical surveys of the water of various wells in the city had been taken by the appellant and these tests had shown that the water was number in any way polluted by reason of the effluent being discharged through the existing channels, that all the papers and reports relating to the tests carried out periodically by the appellant were available for inspection by the respondent Municipality and that they companyld be inspected by appointment.

facts.text: Appellant denied that fertility of soil was adversely affected by effluent discharge.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the fertility of the soil the appellant emphatically denied that the same had been in any way adversely affected by the discharge of the effluent through the existing channels.

facts.text: Appellant stated that complying with notice would cost 8-9 lakhs of rupees, crippling activities.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant further pointed out that the respondent Municipalitys direction that the appellant should arrange the discharge of the effluent through a companyered pucca drain for pumping it over a distance of about 8 miles as shown in the plan would involve an expenditure of nearly 8 to 9 lakhs of rupees which, having regard to the prevailing companyditions, would involve a capital outlay of such an enormous amount as to cripple the appellants activities.

facts.text: Appellant objected to the requisition and expressed inability to carry it out.

anchor.surface_text: Finally, the appellant informed the respondent Municipality that in these circumstances it objected to the requisitions and expressed its inability to carry out the same.

facts.text: Respondent requested Government to appoint Special Officer under s.153A(3).

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then requested the Government to appoint a Special Officer under the provisions of s. 153 A  3  of the Act.

facts.text: Government by order dated May 17, 1958 appointed Mr. T.U. Mehta, District and Sessions Judge, as Special Officer to inquire and complete within 3 months.

anchor.surface_text: The Government by its order dated the 17th of May, 1958, appointed Mr. T.U. Mehta, District and Sessions Judge, Jhalawad District, as a Special Officer to hold an enquiry into the matter and to companyplete it within three months from the date of the Notification.

facts.text: Special Officer framed 7 issues, treated 1-4 as preliminary issues of law.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter came before the Special Officer he recorded the order which is the subject matter of the present appeal by special leave. The Special Officer had framed 7 Issues of which Issues Nos. 1 to 4 were treated by him as preliminary Issues of law.

facts.text: Special Officer decided Issue No. 4 in affirmative: discharge of effluent polluting water and soil is subjective satisfaction of Municipality, beyond scope of enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Officer decided Issue No. 4 in the affirmative and held that the question whether the discharge of the effluent polluted the water and adversely affected the fertility of the soil was one for the subjective satisfaction of the respondent Municipality and was beyond the scope of the enquiry before him.

facts.text: Special Officer held Issue No. 6 does not arise for consideration due to Issue 4.

anchor.surface_text: Having found this he held that Issue No. 6 did number arise for companysideration.

facts.text: Special Officer opined Issue No. 5 (notice mala fide etc.) out of purview.

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with Issue No. 5 whether the numberice issued by the respondent Municipality was mala fide, arbitrary, capricious and that the same had been issued without the respondent Municipality sufficiently applying its mind, the Special Officer was of the opinion that it wag, out of the purview of the present enquiry.

facts.text: Special Officer decided Issues 2 and 3 in favour of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Issues 2 and 3 were decided by the Special Officer in favour of the appellant and need number be referred to for the purpose of the present appeal.

facts.text: Special Officer rejected appellant's contention that ss.153A-153G violate Art.19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: Issue No. I dealt with the question whether ss. 153A to 153G of the Act violated the fundamental rights of the appellant guaranteed under Articles 14, 19 and 31 of the Constitution. ... This companytention was rejected by the Special Officer.

facts.text: Special Officer ordered case to proceed to Issue No.7.

anchor.surface_text: The result of the above findings is that this Tribunal shall number proceed to decide the only remaining Issue which is Issue No. 7. I therefore order that the case should proceed with the determination of this Issue.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Special Officer erred in restricting scope of enquiry, must inquire into existence of nuisance.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, he erred in holding that it was beyond the scope of his enquiry to enquire into the question whether, in fact, the nuisance alleged by the Municipality existed. He had thus denied. himself the jurisdiction-which he did possess and which he ought to have exercised.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside Special Officer's order and allowed appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: As, in our opinion, the Special Officer had wrongly decided that lie companyld number go into the question whether the nuisance existed his order must - be set aside. ... The appeal is accordingly allowed with companyts.

facts.text: Notice issued in June 1956, nearly 3 years ago as of May 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The numberice was issued in June, 1956, nearly 3 years ago.

facts.text: Petition under Art.32 dismissed as unnecessary since appeal succeeded.

anchor.surface_text: A petition  No. 174 of 1958  under Art. 32 of the Constitution was also filed by the appellant. It is unnecessary to pass any formal order on this petition as, the appellant has succeeded in the Civil Appeal No.

arguments.claim: Prior to issuing notice under s.153A(1), existence of nuisance is within subjective satisfaction of Municipality, but after issuing notice and absolute objection under sub-s.(3), it becomes justiciable and Special Officer must enquire into existence of nuisance

anchor.surface_text: Section 153A states Regulation of discharge of effluent containing salt or other chemicals by factories. If it be shown to the satisfaction of the Municipality that the owner or manager of a factory...

arguments.claim: The Special Officer erred in holding that enquiry into nuisance existence was beyond scope; denied himself jurisdiction he possessed

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, he erred in holding that it was beyond the scope of his enquiry to enquire into the question whether, in fact, the nuisance alleged by the Municipality existed. He had thus denied. himself the jurisdiction-which he did possess and which he ought to have exercised.

holdings.text: The Special Officer must enquire into the entire matter where a party objects absolutely to the notice and the requisition contained therein, including the existence of the nuisance.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.153A(3): absolute objection makes nuisance existence justiciable; Special Officer has civil court powers under s.153E; purpose requires inquiry into dispute.

holdings.text: Prior to issuing notice under s.153A(1), existence of nuisance is matter of Municipality's subjective satisfaction which cannot be questioned.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of s.153A(1): Municipality acts on own satisfaction before notice; no dispute if party consents or no reply.

holdings.text: The Special Officer erred in holding that enquiry into existence of nuisance was beyond scope and denied himself jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, he erred in holding that it was beyond the scope of his enquiry to enquire into the question whether, in fact, the nuisance alleged by the Municipality existed. He had thus denied himself the jurisdiction-which he did possess and which he ought to have exercised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Failed to construe s.153A(3) properly; powers under ss.153E-G indicate judicial inquiry into facts.

holdings.text: Special Officer's order must be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: As, in our opinion, the Special Officer had wrongly decided that lie could not go into the question whether the nuisance existed his order must - be set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Due to erroneous refusal to inquire into nuisance existence.

holdings.text: Contention that s.153A offends Art.19(1)(g) does not require decision.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the view which we take, the contention on behalf of the appellant that the provisions of s. 153A of the Act offend Art. 19 of the Constitution does not require to be decided this position is conceded by the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary as appeal succeeds on jurisdictional ground.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly allowed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Special Officer wrongly restricted enquiry scope.

holdings.text: Petition under Art.32 unnecessary; no formal order needed.

anchor.surface_text: A petition No. 174 of 1958 under Art. 32 of the Constitution was also filed by the appellant. It is unnecessary to pass any formal order on this petition as, the appellant has succeeded in the Civil Appeal No.

We must point out, however, that the enquiry should be companyleted without undue delay. The numberice was issued in June, 1956, nearly 3 years ago. Proceedings of this kind ought to be handled with the utmost expedition because if a nuisance exists it should be removed without delay in order to preserve the health of the compunity and the fertility of the soil. The appeal is accordingly allowed with costs.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; Special Officer's order set aside; no decision on constitutional challenge needed; writ petition rendered infructuous

proceedings ought to be handled with the utmost expedition

The concept describes Section 153E as conferring judicial powers for enquiry into factual disputes like nuisance existence, which grounds the holding that the Special Officer erred by excluding such enquiry from scope and denying jurisdiction.
The concept's indication that Section 153E includes powers for nuisance enquiry supports the holding criticizing the Special Officer's erroneous limitation of scope.
The concept defining Section 153E powers to include nuisance enquiry addresses the issue concerning the erroneous restriction of enquiry scope.
